title: If you don't want to be treated like a child, don't act like one.
body:
"I got banned because (player) did (Something I didn't like) ."

This is a recurring theme among players who end up penalized or even permanently banned.  Their actions are the result of someone else's actions, and therefore they should not be penalized for it.  We see it over and over again.  Someone said something, did something, didn't do something, didn't say something and that just set them off.

These players are lacking in impulse control.  Impulse control is being able to control one's actions and not  just saying or doing everything that pops into one's head. It is a life skill that most people learn at a very young age.

If you are one of these players, some of the resources below may be valuable for you.  Yes, I know they're geared towards children, but the concepts are still solid.

> Sometime between the third and fourth birthdays, many kids will begin developing impulse control skills to help them control responses and behaviors. The Illinois Early Learning Project advises that kids between the ages of 3 and 5 are old enough to learn impulse control. You might compare learning impulse control to building muscles, though. Just as it takes time to make muscles stronger, it takes time for children to learn how to control emotions and actions.
> 
> https://howtoadult.com/age-kids-impulse-control-1267.html

More information on Impulse Control:

> Impulse Control: The developing capacity to wait for needs to be met, to inhibit potentially hurtful behavior, and to act according to social expectations
> 
> https://www.cde.ca.gov/sp/cd/re/itf09socemofdimpc.asp

Some tips on developing Impulse Control.

> Children develop controlled impulses as part of their overall development.  The very young child does not have these skills.  In fact, there are those of us who have difficulty refraining from a second cookie as adults.  Impulse control requires will power, delayed gratification, and self-control.  For the child who struggles with development, sensory processing, attention, physical limitations, cognitive delays, or social impairments, the ability to control ones impulses is very difficult.  These individuals are cognitively and automatically focused on the underlying needs.  When other needs such as sensory or balance are the primary focus, it can be quite difficult to refrain from impulses.
> 
> https://www.theottoolbox.com/2017/03/how-to-teach-kids-impulse-control.html

**Evidence**
As evidence for the issue identified above, I'm going to start linking threads here that show the described issue as I see them pop up on the boards.

Get off the highroad, because I promise you you've had a moment where you flip your lid in a game. Whether or not you get banned for it, when you're in the moment it doesn't matter what the consequences are. Various circumstance definitely overpower senses and logic, and scratching your head wondering why people think they shouldn't get banned (even if they are in the wrong) is just silly.

Why shouldn't someone be angry over someone trolling in a ranked game?  this isn't a fun game like say, Lethal League, where you don't have to commit much time to a match if you don't want to. In this game, you forfeit so much progress in the ranked system and time in game if you don't win, and when someone intentionally tries to ruin your game, what else did you expect them to do in the heat of the moment? Ignore it? Move on? The punishment system for going afk just frustrates people even more cause now they can't leave, and the game is already a lost cause. 

Same thing with flamers in chat. If they're saying something that's not true, e.g. "GG retarded bot" you immediately want to refute it because it's degrading.

In the big picture, sure, it makes sense to judge people in a sense of "lol just report at end of game bruh its so easy just have self control" but it's really not that easy when you're actually in the game, and I'd like you to step off the highroad for just a second to really consider someone else with extremely different circumstances both in game and IRL.

and then to pour salt on the wound if you get banned for doing something (or saying something) of course someone is going to try and say that "I did 'blank' because this player did 'blank'

so maybe claiming people who lose control for even just one game are "children" isn't the most insightful thing to say. It's probably the most infuriating thing I've ever heard, and I've never even been banned or chat restricted.

First of all, losing your cool in the heat of the moment and not understanding why you were penalized for it after you've thought about it are two different things.  It is rarely an issue of the player not knowing _why_ he was penalized and almost always an issue of the player thinking it's okay to lose his cool and go off on other players.

That said, sure things have happened in game that infuriated me.  I pause, take a deep breath, mute those involved, and then continue playing.  At the end of the day, it's a game, nothing more, nothing less.  If the game is so stressful for you that you cannot control yourself while playing it, it may not be the healthiest game for you.
 
> Why shouldn't someone be angry over someone trolling in a ranked game?  this isn't a fun game like say, Lethal League, where you don't have to commit much time to a match if you don't want to. In this game, you forfeit so much progress in the ranked system and time in game if you don't win, and when someone intentionally tries to ruin your game, what else did you expect them to do in the heat of the moment? Ignore it? Move on? The punishment system for going afk just frustrates people even more cause now they can't leave, and the game is already a lost cause. 
 
> Same thing with flamers in chat. If they're saying something that's not true, e.g. "GG retarded bot" you immediately want to refute it because it's degrading.

Nowhere in my post or in any of the links I posted did I state that you shouldn't get angry.  Go ahead and check, you won't find it.  If you're angry, then be angry.  But keep it out of the chat and out of the game.  Control the _impulse_ to go off in chat, because not only does it result in you being penalized, but it also reduces your chances of winning and worsens the experience for your teammates, even those not involved in your spat.

> In the big picture, sure, it makes sense to judge people in a sense of "lol just report at end of game bruh its so easy just have self control" but it's really not that easy when you're actually in the game, and I'd like you to step off the highroad for just a second to really consider someone else with extremely different circumstances both in game and IRL.

There is no situation where it "makes sense" to rage, flame, or troll in game, regardless of what else has happened or is happening in the game, certainly not if you're still trying to win.  Raging, flaming, or trolling in retaliation is a 100% emotion, 0% logical response that creates a lose/lose situation for all involved, every time.

> so maybe claiming people who lose control for even just one game are "children" isn't the most insightful thing to say. It's probably the most infuriating thing I've ever heard, and I've never even been banned or chat restricted.

The original post was directed at people who were penalized.  For those people, it's unlikely to be a single game occurrence.  It is a pattern of behavior that they should be aware of, sooner rather than later, for their benefit as well as those that end up playing with them.
